events.text:

Mateus Ferreira - Programmer

children.text: Reset global variables to prevent traces from previous sessions.
Setup the player by adding its graphics to the collider as a child.
Receive and store input from the player to be used later in many situations.
Toggle input left.
Toggle input right.
Toggle input up.
Toggle input down.
Calculate both axis and looking angle based on the player input.
Move the player horizontally based on its horizontal axis.
Simulate player jump.
Only update the animations if the Platform behavior is enabled, which means the hookshot skill is not currently being used.
Mirror the player graphics based on its horizontal axis.
Change the animation states depending on what the player is currently doing.
Walk animation.
Idle animation.
Jump animation.
Fall animation.
Spawn different types of dust particles depending on the player actions.
Walking dust.
Landing dust.
Jumping dust.
Setup the trigger position to match to platform top mechanism.
Destroy the player object and create a giant white flash.
Setup the giant white flash and animate it to disappear after some time.
Interpolate the camera position to constantly track the player with smooth movement.

parameters.x: lerp(Self.X, PlayerCollision.X + CAMERAOFFSETX, CameraSpeed * TARGETFRAMERATE * dt)
parameters.y: lerp(Self.Y, PlayerCollision.Y + CAMERAOFFSETY, CameraSpeed * TARGETFRAMERATE * dt)

children.text: Create a screen shake effect to add more intensity to specific actions.
Restart the game.
Setup the torch by spawning a fire object in front of it and randomizing its starting frame to make environment more dynamic.
How fast each rope animations will be executed.
How far the rope can go from player's position.
Start the hookshot event sequence.
Only allow the hookshot to be used if the Platform behavior is enabled, which means the hookshot is not being used already.

actions.text: Remove any residual motion from the player by resetting both vectors.
Disable the Platform behavior, so all the movements can be controlled by the Tween behavior.
Cast a ray in front of the player, using its own width as a reference (it will be a positive value when looking right and a negative value when looking left).
Change the player animation to match the hookshot skill.

children.text: If the ray collides with a solid object, spawn and setup the rope object.

actions.text: Make the rope invisible by setting its width to zero.
Point the rope towards hit object by also using the player's width as a reference.
Tween a value from zero to whatever amount of frames contained in the rope object, this will later be used to cycle through each frame.

children.text: Is the rope reach a solid object, extend it until it matches the distance between the player and the solid object.
If the rope doesn't reach a solid object, extend it as much as possible based on the established limit.
If the rope reach a solid object, retract it while also moving the player towards the hit object.

actions.text: Attach the rope to the player, so it look like the rope is pulling it.
Move the player towards the hit object.
Retract the rope with the exact same time as the player movement.
Create a small hit effect where the rope lands.

children.text: Once the rope is completely retracted, destroy it and give control back to the player.
If the rope doesn't reach a solid object, simply retract.
After the retract animation is over, destroy the hope and give control back to the player.
While the rope offset animation is playing, update the rope object using rounded values, so it looks like a stable frame-by-frame animation.

If there's any collision with the ground while the player is moving, stop any rope related animation, give control back to the player and make sure the player is not overlapping the ground anymore by slowly moving it in the opposite direction in a loop.
Also leave a trail of "ghosts" behind the player if there are no collisions.
Destroy the trail object after its animation is over to prevent any sort of CPU overload.
Restart the game.
Close the game.
